\date{\today}
\maketitle

\begin{abstract}
We present a tight binding theory to analyze the  motion of
electrons between carbon nanotubes bundled into a carbon nanotube
rope.  The theory is developed starting from a description of the
propagating Bloch waves on ideal tubes, and   the effects of
intertube motion are treated  perturbatively in this basis.
Expressions for the interwall tunneling amplitudes between  states
on neighboring tubes are derived which show the dependence on
chiral angles and intratube crystal momenta. We find that
conservation of crystal momentum along the tube direction suppresses 
interwall coherence in a carbon nanorope containing tubes with
random chiralities. Numerical calculations are presented which
indicate that electronic states in a rope are localized in the
transverse direction with a coherence length corresponding to a
tube diameter.
\end{abstract}
\pacs{PACS: 72.80.Rj, 73.40.Gk, 61.16.Ch  }
